723988f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square South - 6th Avenue
723988f-a.text:
Washington Square South (West 4th Street), east from 4th Stree
between oth avenue and Macdougal Street.
The Washington Square Methodist Episcopal Church is in the for ground, at 135 West 4th Street. The house at the corner of Street and Washington Scuare West is shortly to be replaced an apartment building. The Judson tower is between Sullivan Thompson Streets. Across the park, on Washington Square Eas are the buildings belonging to New York University.
April 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
723988f-a.folder: Washington Square South & 6th Avenue, Manhattan, NY

709306f-c.text:
Sixth Avenue, west side, from Washington Place to Waverly Place, showing prominently St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church and its adjoining Sunday School Building.
View 1 shows the absence of the Sixth Avenue Elevated. The tall apartment house at the right is at
the S.E. corner of Waverly Place.
View 1: January 17, 1939
View 2: March 15, 1932
View 3: May 5, 1930
P. L. Sperr

Handwritten: Plaque on church reads: "This edifice is the oldest Catholic Church building in Manhattan, erected in 1833"

709308f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from Washington Place to Waverly Place showing this frontage cleared.
Subway construction necessitated same.
Views 1 and 2 are similar, while No. 3 is from a point of vantagge slightly to the north. Outstanding hhere is the 9 story apartment house, the VVan Voorst.
This bears No. 125 Waverly Place.
View No. 1: February 24, 1933
View o. 3,2: March 11, 1932
P. L. Sperr

709307f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from Washington Place showing the cleared frontage utilized as an automobile lot. This extends one block to Waverly Place. Note there the 9 story apartment house, the Van Voorst.
View 1: June 1, 1935
View 2: March 8, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709307f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from Washington Place showing the cleared frontage utilized as an automobile lot. This extends one block to Waverly Place. Note there the 9 story apartment house, the Van Voorst.
View 1: June 1, 1935
View 2: March 8, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709309f-b.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from a point between Washington and Waverly Places and across the latter (in View 1; north from Waverly Place in View 2) showing prominently the "El" demolition which has progressed to this point. The West 8th Street station of same appears in a skeletal condition against the new Detention House for Women and the clock tower of the Jefferson Market Court. The iron work shack and lot on the right of View 2 are being utilized by subway contractors who are building, at this date, a
new subway under the thoroughfare.
January 25, 1939
P. L. Sperr

709309f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, north from a point between Washington and Waverly Places and across the latter (in View 1; north from Waverly Place in View 2) showing prominently the "El" demolition which has progressed to this point. 709310f-a.text:
Sixth AAvenue, north from a point between Washington and Waverly Places and across the latter as Viewed from the west side of the Avenue. Shown under demolition is the "El" structure, long a feature of this vicinity. Work on same has reached Waverly Place. Note also the subway construction shack there. The 9 story apartment house partially shown at the right of Views 1 and 2 is the Van Voorst, No. 123-125 Waverly Place. At the left margin appears the clock tower of the Jefferson Market Court. To the center, on the horizon, is the
Empire State Building.
January 7, 1939
Views 1 and 2
View 3: January 25, 1939
P. L. Sperr

724024f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square West - 6th Avenue
724024f-b.text:
(1)
Washington Square Park, the central and northeastern part, seen from
Washington Square West.
In the right center is the new comfort station, which early in 1928 keplaced the old wooden one. In the center is the fountain, used as a children's swimming pool. On the farther side of the drive
is the statue of Qaribaldi, erected around 1890.
August, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing the builoings on either side of the northeastern corner. Between the old houses on Washington Sduare North, and the new New York University building (about 1900) on Washington Square East, 1ises a new apantment building at 1 University Place, built in 1929. In the left foreground is the Washington Arch in the permanent form erected after the Washington Centennial of 1889.
Auguat, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.  D o0S
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  NEG H :1A E
